Reactions going on here:
2 Hg(SCN)2 -->2 HgS + CS2+ C3N4
CS2 burns:
CS2 + 3 O2 --> CO2 + 2 SO2
Also some HgS burns:
HgS + O2 --> Hg + SO2
These are the gases causing the puffing effect of C3N4 (the yellow stuff), as Nile said.
Some C3N4 will also break down:
2 C3N4 --> (CN)2 + N2
Yes, it produces cyanogen.

It's actually a somewhat popular theory that the reason it got the name Pharaohs serpent is because it resembles a group of writhing snakes. Some historians actually believe this reaction might have been the basis for the story in the bible when pharaohs court alchemists challenged moses to turn his staff into a snake. It would be reasonable in ancient times to believe that some divine power was at work when this reaction was performed and so closely resembled snakes summoned seemingly out of thin air.

Hey Nile Red how do you clean up your fume hood area after the mercury (II) thiocyanate reaction. I imagine there must be some mercury dust coating every surface that you would want to clean. I have heard that copper powder or granules can ad as a mercury sponge to clean surfaces with small amounts of mercury. just wondering if you had any insight. My professor said she will let me do the reaction if I can find a good way to clean up the waste. Also I was wondering if you know any more about the C3N4 produced as a solid in the primary reaction. I haven't been able to find much info on what this is, and I don't think that it is graphitic carbon nitride that has the same molecular formula. so if you have any information on what that is that would be great also.

This got me thinking on a geology side-tangent. I remember a particular college chemistry teacher (on Youtube) in his discussion of 17th century alchemy that it was a common belief that metals grew like plants and had 'seeds' because ore veins looked a bit like these snakes in terms of structure. Sounds like a lot of the mining ore got shaken out or concentrated by similar types of exothermic reactions, probably in conditions with a lot of ground water colliding it with a mineral deposit.

very good presentation indeed...I have a question please...Its about Goulard's extract which is mainly lead subacetate...well the official pharmacopoeia procedure states that 250 gm lead acetate + 175 gm lead mono oxide dissolved and titre to 1 liter..the filtrate is isolated and called strong solution and the 12.5 ml of the strong solution is diluted further on demand to form the diluted medical lead sub acetate...the question is if I had lead subacetate powder haw can I prepare the diluted form of this extract to use it in my pharmacy...my calculations lead me to use 0.003 dilution that is 3 grams of lead sub acetate in 1 liter...any ideas please?
